title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how urbanization leads to the formation of urban heat islands, such as any of the following:

· Urban buildings can block wind currents, increasing local temperatures.

· Urban building materials/structures such as roads, sidewalks, and/or buildings hold in heat, causing the temperatures to increase.

· Urban areas have fewer trees, resulting in less shade/less transpiration, causing temperatures to increase.

· Urban areas have large numbers of vehicles/air conditioners/machinery that produce waste heat, causing temperatures to increase.

The response describes how urbanization leads to the formation of urban heat islands, such as one of the following:

· Urban buildings can block wind currents, increasing local temperatures.

· Urban building materials/structures such as roads, sidewalks, and/or buildings hold in heat, causing the temperatures to increase.

· Urban areas have fewer trees, resulting in less shade/less transpiration, causing temperatures to increase.

· Urban areas have large numbers of vehicles/air conditioners/machinery that produce waste heat, causing temperatures to increase.

title: Part B(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not propose a reasonable solution that could help lower the temperature increases caused by urban heat islands, such as any of the following:

· Plant green roofs on buildings/plant vegetation around buildings/increase green space

· Use cool/reflective/lighter-colored surfaces on roofs/buildings/surfaces

· Increase efficiency of a system that produces waste heat (vehicles, air conditioners)

· Decrease use of a system that produces waste heat (vehicles, air conditioners)

The response proposes a reasonable solution that could help lower the temperature increases caused by urban heat islands, such as one of the following:

· Plant green roofs on buildings/plant vegetation around buildings/increase green space

· Use cool/reflective/lighter-colored surfaces on roofs/buildings/surfaces

· Increase efficiency of a system that produces waste heat (vehicles, air conditioners)

· Decrease use of a system that produces waste heat (vehicles, air conditioners)

title: Part B(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not justify the solution in part (b)(i) by providing an additional benefit, other than reducing temperatures in urban heat islands, such as any of the following:

Plant green roofs on buildings/plant vegetation around buildings/increase green space (solution in (b)(i))

· Provides food crops

· Creates habitat for biodiversity

· Slows/captures runoff

· Insulates buildings, which reduces heating/cooling costs

title: Part C(i)

Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The students must show their work for full credit. Students must include units and multiplication by 100 to yield a true percentage in the setup.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the Northern Hemisphere receives more solar energy from the Sun between June and August than the Southern Hemisphere receives between June and August, such as any of the following:

· During June through August, the Northern Hemisphere is tilted toward the Sun and receives more direct solar energy (per unit area) than the Southern Hemisphere.

· During June through August, the Northern Hemisphere is tilted toward the Sun and has more hours of sunlight.

The response explains why the Northern Hemisphere receives more solar energy from the Sun between June and August than the Southern Hemisphere receives between June and August, such as one of the following:

· During June through August, the Northern Hemisphere is tilted toward the Sun and receives more direct solar energy (per unit area) than the Southern Hemisphere.

· During June through August, the Northern Hemisphere is tilted toward the Sun and has more hours of sunlight.
